summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing press coverage of the Epstein estate's plan to establish a victims' compensation fund managed by Kenneth Feinberg, and reporting on new civil lawsuits filed against the estate by accusers. It reveals legal strategies, attorney objections, and ongoing investigations into Epstein's associates.

events.title: NYT Reports on Potential Epstein Victims' Fund
events.description: The New York Times reports that lawyers for Jeffrey Epstein's estate are considering setting up a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers, with Kenneth Feinberg retained to design it.

events.title: New Lawsuits Filed Against Epstein Estate
events.description: Boies Schiller Flexner files at least three new lawsuits in SDNY on behalf of women alleging sexual abuse by Epstein, naming executors Indyke and Kahn.

events.title: Federal Case Against Epstein Dismissed
events.description: Federal prosecutors dismiss the sex-trafficking indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his suicide, starting a one-year clock for crime victims to file civil lawsuits in New York.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleads guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution from a minor; court filings estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls.

events.title: SDNY Meets with Epstein Accusers
events.description: Representatives from the U.S. Attorney's Office in Manhattan meet with accusers and lawyers to discuss the ongoing investigation into Epstein's associates.

keyFacts: Epstein's estate, valued at about $577 million, is proposing a voluntary 'claims resolution program' managed by Kenneth Feinberg to compensate accusers, but faces resistance from some victims' lawyers.
At least three new civil lawsuits were filed against the Epstein estate in November 2019, with allegations detailing abuse by Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell between 1995 and 2002.
The executors of Epstein's estate are his longtime lawyer Darren Indyke and accountant Richard Kahn, who are named as defendants in the new lawsuits.
The document highlights ongoing legal feuds, including between attorney David Boies and former professor Alan Dershowitz, who denies allegations of sexual misconduct in Epstein's orbit.
Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are continuing to investigate potential charges against people who may have helped Epstein, indicating the criminal probe extends beyond Epstein himself.
